entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, Antoine Riard addressed concerns about front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces, particularly in relation to the CivKit architecture. Front-running refers to the practice of entering into trades with advance knowledge of upcoming transactions that could influence prices. Riard proposed a design assumption where Mary the Maker publishes a limit order, which can be executed by Bob the bulletin board operator or relayed to Terry the Taker. If Terry decides not to execute the trade, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board. Riard argued that this model resembles a brokerage rather than an exchange structure, suggesting that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete with Bob on quoting prices.To mitigate front-running risks, Riard provided two security paradigms. The first involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring latency anomalies. This approach relies on watchtower-like infrastructure and allows makers to disqualify misbehaving boards. However, it is not perfect and could still be exploited by boards. The second paradigm suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or a similar consensus mechanism. In this model, incoming board offers become consensus items, and federation members are paid for publishing only after a consensus proposal is adopted. Riard also emphasized the importance of providing a good user experience and focusing on execution quality to attract market activity and liquidity.Riard acknowledged that front-running can be seen as a positive sign of active participants and liquidity in a market. However, he also noted that front-running resistance should be considered depending on the types of trades involved. For example, for commodities, liquidity may be lower due to factors like production cycles and weather conditions. Riard discussed the potential use of social assumptions, such as over-the-counter trading, in certain contexts. He suggested that compatibility between OTC and public boards could allow traffic flows between them and enable users to choose the trading approach that best suits their needs.In conclusion, the CivKit architecture offers a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces. The design allows for the customization of front-running resistance parameters based on real-world deployments and the types of trades involved. Riard expressed his optimism about addressing front-running concerns and emphasized the importance of providing a good user experience and attracting market activity.Antoine Riard, along with Nicholas Gregory and Ray Youssef, is working on a peer-to-peer market system that enables censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design combines the Nostr architecture of simple relays announcing trade orders to their clients with Lightning onion routing infrastructure. The market boards are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, each operating autonomously and in competition. The trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication.One of the main concerns addressed in the paper is front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces. Front-running involves entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security to capitalize on the trade. To mitigate this risk, the paper proposes two security paradigms. The first paradigm involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards and monitoring the latency for anomalies. The second paradigm involves running the bulletin boards as a federation under Honey Badger BFT, where incoming board offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members before adoption.The paper also discusses the concept of "front-running resistance" as a fundamental property desired in a peer-to-peer marketplace. The level of front-running resistance aimed by the market participants is expected to be heavily influenced by the types of trades considered. Different types of trades may have different levels of liquidity and exposure to front-running risks.The researchers propose the introduction of a Web-of-Stakes to enable the scoring of trades, counterparties, and service operators. This reputation paradigm could be composed with decentralized identifiers and other Web-of-Trust techniques. Additionally, an incentive framework for service operators is proposed through privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments, following the lineaments of IETF's Privacy Pass.The whitepaper goes deep into the architecture of the system, combining the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure. The researchers plan to gradually release code and modules, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They aim to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients.Overall, the paper presents a detailed analysis of the proposed peer-to-peer market system, addressing front-running risks and proposing security paradigms and incentive frameworks. The researchers welcome feedback from the community.
